the last couple of GPT-4o updates have made the personality too sycophant-y and annoying (even though there are some very good parts of it), and we are working on fixes asap, some today and some this week.

at some point will share our learnings from this, it's been interesting.

we started rolling back the latest update to GPT-4o last night

it's now 100% rolled back for free users and we'll update again when it's finished for paid users, hopefully later today

we're working on additional fixes to model personality and will share more in the coming days

Need to track bugs, plan features, or gather feedback?  GitHub Issues makes it easy! Learn how to create, manage, and collaborate on all your project tasks effectively.

When sensitive data leaks, assume the worst.

Stop chasing degrees of exposure. Treat it as total, act fast, and protect what matters most.

GitHub Copilot understands more languages than just English. 

Check out how Copilot’s agent mode autonomously builds a product page from scratch, handling multiple files and validation—all while understanding and communicating in Hindi.

Ready to build a REST API?  We'll walk you through creating a Python/Flask backend with GitHub Copilot's help, covering database setup, user authentication, endpoints, and more.

Let's start building!

The biggest revelation from Deepseek is that Open Source has won.  For a 1% difference in performance, it will be difficult for OpenAI to justify its price when the competition is free and formidable.  -from my interview with Bloomberg

01 .ai trained a GPT-4 competitor using just 2,000 GPUs and $3M, while achieving competitive performance. Through innovative engineering and optimization

Great work on strong open models by the Qwen team. One thing I appreciate is the release of both MoE (strong) and dense (convenient) models.

System prompt patching is quite common. 

At least with system prompts hackers can provide transparency to some degree - imagine what gets backed into models via training...

Yap score tracking task in action.

ChatGPT did a web search and also pulled info from X.  This shows how easy it is to have untrusted data in a chat that might manipulate result.

Project DeepWiki

Up-to-date documentation you can talk to, for every repo in the world.

Think Deep Research for GitHub – powered by Devin.

It’s free for open-source, no sign-up! 
Visit deepwiki com or just swap github → deepwiki on any repo URL:

thanks for all the love for deepwiki! 
i remember how i used to always have to dump github repos into insanely long prompts to feed context to LLMs. (that’s why i built repo2prompt a year ago) 

now i just use deepwiki

how can i make it better for you?

I expected LLMs to have more faithful reasoning as they gained more from reasoning. Bigger capability gains suggested to me that models would use the stated reasoning more.

Sadly, we only saw small gains to faithfulness from reasoning training, which also quickly plateau-ed.

Search has become one of our most popular & fastest growing features, with over 1 billion web searches just in the past week

Today is the start of a new era of natively multimodal AI innovation.

Today, we’re introducing the first Llama 4 models: Llama 4 Scout and Llama 4 Maverick —  our most advanced models yet and the best in their class for multimodality.

Llama 4 Scout
• 17B-active-parameter model

“We built this place on open source…”
Meta Chief Product Officer Chris Cox took to the stage to kick off LlamaCon 2025, reflecting on our long legacy of open source contributions.

Cox also gave a special shoutout to our partners, who’ve helped make it possible to get started building with Llama right off the bat—regardless of your development environment. Because the Llama stack is modular, it’s easy to plug and play and switch between component parts.
And we want to help businesses scale. That’s why Llama 4 packs a lot of performance into as small a package as possible.

Our free plan just got a major upgrade.

All free users now get 25 prompt credits for premium model usage, unlimited usage of Cascade Base (even in Write mode), unlimited fast Tab completions, and access to App Deploys.

Also, we changed our logo!

GPT-4.1 and o4-mini models will now be available at a discounted price for all users:  

GPT-4.1 and o4-mini-medium = 0.25 credits/prompt 

o4-mini-high = 0.5 credits/prompt

Attention has been the key component for most advances in LLMs, but it can’t scale to long context. Does this mean we need to find an alternative? 

Presenting Titans: a new architecture with attention and a meta in-context memory that learns how to memorize at test time. Titans

.
@GoogleAI
 has dropped a very interesting study

They introduced new types of attentional bias strategies in LLMs and reimagined the "forgetting" process, replacing it with "retention."

All of this is wrapped up in Miras – their new framework for designing efficient AI

It’s All Connected: A Journey Through Test-Time Memorization, Attentional Bias, Retention, and Online Optimization

From Google Research. Introduces Miras, a general framework to design deep learning architectures based on four choices of: associative memory architecture,

Qwen has just released Qwen 3 with an open-source license and 8 different sizes.

Available for free (see below)

To use Qwen 3 locally:

1. Download LM Studio (https://lmstudio.ai)
2. Search for "Qwen 3"
3. Select the size you want

(I recommend 4B, 8B, 14B or 32B depending on the power of your computer)

4. Click on "New Chat" and load the model you have just downloaded!

An example of the limitations of semantic VAD. Humans have no issues disambiguating utterances 1 and 2 as the word "student" is pronounced slightly differently in the middle vs end of a sentence.
Looking forward to chatting about realtime AI!

Yeah, this is another form of semantic VAD that leverages the LLM's understanding of the utterance to detect incomplete sentences. However, users sometimes pause at valid sentence breaks, so this approach isn't bulletproof. Ultimately, we need VAD evals and benchmarks.

Just published today's edition of my newsletter.

 Model Context Protocol (MCP) 101

(consider subscribing, its FREE, I publish it daily, and you will get a 1300+page Python book sent to your email instantly  )

LLMs reason poorly when asked for short answers, as this conflicts with their internal step-by-step thinking, causing sharp performance drops (over 40% lower accuracy on >2 step problems).

This conflict leads to instability (accuracy <10% on 6-step problems) and bias.

The paper

LLMs using chain-of-thought often generate excessive reflection and transition steps, increasing inference cost and sometimes degrading performance.

This paper introduces SEAL (Steerable rEAsoning caLibration), a training-free method that identifies and reduces these
